Title.evidence: Continuous Monitoring of Vital Signs on General Wards: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either continuous monitoring of vital signs or usual care

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either continuous monitoring of vital signs or usual care with intermittent measurements

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether continuous monitoring of vital signs improves patient outcomes compared to usual care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hospital mortality, assessed during the hospital stay.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods varied across studies

Number_Randomised.evidence: Seven RCTs with 1284 participants were included, with 664 randomised to continuous monitoring and 620 to usual care.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No statistically significant differences were observed in hospital mortality (OR 0.95, 95% CI 0.59–1.53, p = 0.84)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were not consistently reported across studies.
